Title:
Host-shifts and ecological speciation drive diversification
in a lineage of bryoparasitic host-castrating fungi.
Keywords:
coevolution, cophylogeny, cospeciation, pathogen,
parasite, Lizonia, Lizonia alpina, Polytrichaceae
Abstract:
Lizonia species are necrotrophic fungal pathogens of
polytrichaceous mosses that preferentially infect the bryophytesÂ’ male
reproductive organs, effectively castrating their hosts. High
host-specificity within the genus suggests cospeciation as a plausible
mechanism driving diversification within this pathogen lineage. Species
delimitations in Lizonia have previously been based solely on morphology
and ecology, and as such, a 3 gene phylogenetic analysis was undertaken
to better explore species-level diversity in the genus and to ensure
accurate cophylogenetic analysis. Lizonia represented a monophyletic
lineage within Didymellaceae (Pleosporales) and two previously
unrecognized lineages in the genus were identified: Lizonia alpina sp.
nov. occurring on Polytrichastrum alpinum and a putative new species
occurring on Polytrichum juniperinum. Only minimal cospeciation was
detected in the Lizonia-Polytrichaceae system using two cophylogeny
analysis tools (Parafit and Jane 4.0). Instead, host-switching and
subsequent ecological speciation is the driving force behind pathogen
diversification. It is not clear whether specific dispersal and
reproductive mechanisms in the fungus facilitate this speciation by
encouraging reproductive isolation, or whether coevolution between host
and pathogen and subsequent fitness reduction in immigrants and hybrids
rapidly creates genetic divergence among populations in the absence of
reproductive isolation.
